caption_original: Thanks to the Montreal Protocol, 99% of ozone depleting substances are eliminated in Canada and the hole is repairing itself. But, the work is not done!  Canada is committed to a full recovery of the ozone layer and action on climate change.

caption_original: The Montreal Protocol is one of the most successful global agreements ever. Together with the world, Canada stopped the thinning of the ozone layer. And now, 30 years later we are coming together under this agreement to stop climate change with the Kigali Amendment.

caption_original:
Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). 

We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. 

Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.
caption_cleaned: Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

caption_original:
Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. 

At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the 2017 UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. 

SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted. http://ow.ly/5J5C30gAhJl

SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted.

During the first meeting of the new #PoweringPastCoal Alliance, Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, and the United Kingdom‚Äôs Minister of State for Climate Change and Industry, Claire Perry, were joined by partners unified in action to accelerate the clean growth economy through the rapid phase-out of traditional coal-fired electricity.

Today is Human Settlements [AKA Cities] Day at COP23.

In Canada, about 12% of national greenhouse gas emissions come from heating and cooling homes and buildings. If we want to leave a cleaner planet, cities must adapt to deal with climate change. To address this issue, Canada is investing in climate-resilient infrastructure and standards. 

Learn more about sustainable and efficient homes and buildings:

caption_original:
Today is Health Day at COP23. The Government of Canada is committed to reducing short-lived climate pollutants that are warming the planet and impacting our health, the quality of the air we breathe and the environment.

By using clean technology to reduce short-lived climate pollutants, we will grow the economy and meet our climate change and air quality goals. Cleaner air leads to improved human health, including fewer asthma symptoms, a reduced risk of premature death and fewer heart related issues. http://ow.ly/oIci30gwIds

caption_original:
Today is Industry Day at COP23. It reminds us that transitioning to cleaner sources of energy is not only good for the environment,but good for our economy too. 

More and more, renewable sources of energy are becoming cost competitive with traditional sources. We know there are over $20 trillion in new opportunities for investments in emerging markets between now and 2030.

Canadian businesses are well-positioned to seize the opportunities that clean growth presents; resulting in new jobs, new technologies and less pollution. The Government of Canada is investing strategically to support growth across all sectors of the economy.
